No. But I believe some things aren't as cut and dried as science, atheists, or religious folks would have us believe. I have been both religious and atheist at different times in my life. But then the universe subtly reminds me to remain agnostic. My mother died last summer. Expected due to poor health but the speed of her decline still took us by surprise. A month before she went to the hospital we had started to reconnect while packing her home to move her to a closer and smaller place. Myself, my sister, and mom had a chance to reconnect through pictures and family heirlooms, toys, records, old boxes of memories. And then before she could move she fell ill, back in the hospital, eleven days of anesthesia struggling to heal and then she was gone. Eleven days the three of us stayed together. The packing remained, tears were shed in an empty home. A home for many years shared by just myself, my sister, and my mother. I would take breaks in the front yard before and after her death, admiring the spring flowers. The front of her house and driveway were filled with blooming tiger lilies. They were my favorite. I didn't expect an answer but I felt better talking to her in the house as if she were still there. I did ask, foolishly I thought, for some sign that she still existed. Of course there was no answer. Or was there? Almost a month after she died there was a thunderstorm. In the morning the sun was warm and bright. And I sadly made the drive back to the empty shell of her home to continue packing. I walked up to the door and I saw them. Lying on the threshold, three perfect tiger lilies. The date was August 3rd, the day before my birthday. I took the picture as they were, interlocked, touching, the three of us symbolically represented by three delicate flowers that survived a storm. I will never be able to believe she's living in heaven in a gold mansion, just as I can never believe she was just a collection of atoms, an animal in clothes. But I believe somehow, she was there on that doorstep that night...  ...to leave a final message. "I will see you again... but not yet... not yet..." - Juba

Here are six logical explanations for the ghostly presence : 1. ELECTROMAGNETIC FIELDS For decades, a Canadian neuroscientist named Michael Persinger has been studying the effects of electromagnetic fields on people’s perceptions of ghosts, hypothesizing that pulsed magnetic fields, imperceptible on a conscious level, can make people feel as if there is a “presence” in the room with them by causing unusual activity patterns in the brain’s temporal lobes. Persinger has studied people in his lab wearing a so-called “God Helmet,” finding that certain patterns of weak magnetic fields over someone’s head for 15 to 30 minutes can create the perception that there’s an invisible presence in the room. Some subsequent research has pushed back on this theory, arguing that people were responding to the suggestion that they would feel a ghostly presence, rather than to the electromagnetic field. However, Persinger counters that this experiment followed very different protocols than his own research. Other scientists have also found that environments that have a reputation for being haunted often feature unusual magnetic fields. 2. INFRASOUND Infrasound is sound at levels so low humans can’t hear it (though other animals, like elephants, can). Low frequency vibrations can cause distinct physiological discomfort. Scientists studying the effects of wind turbines and traffic noise near residences have found that low-frequency noise can cause disorientation, feelings of panic, changes in heart rate and blood pressure, and other effects that could easily be associated with being visited by a ghost . For instance, in a 1998 paper on natural causes of hauntings, engineer Vic Tandy describes working for a medical equipment manufacturer, whose labs included a reportedly haunted room. Whenever Tandy worked in this particular lab, he felt depressed and uncomfortable, often hearing and seeing odd things—including an apparition that definitely looked like a ghost. Eventually, he discovered that the room was home to an 19 Hz standing wave coming from a fan, which was sending out the inaudible vibrations that caused the disorienting effects. Further studies also show links between infrasound and bizarre sensations like getting chills down the spine or feeling uneasy. 3. MOLD Shane Rogers, an engineering professor at Clarkson University, has spent the past few months touring reportedly haunted locations looking for not-so-paranormal activity: mold growth. Preliminary research indicates that some molds can cause symptoms that sound pretty ghostly—like irrational fear and dementia. “I’ve watched a lot of ghost shows,” he tells mental_floss, and began to wonder “if there’s some kind of link there, where we might be able to explain why people are having these feelings.” So far in the data collection process, “it’s hard to say whether that’s a contributing factor or not, but anecdotally we are seeing these [toxic molds] exist in places that are haunted.” 4. CARBON MONOXIDE POISONING In 1921, a doctor named W.H. Wilmer published an odd story about a haunted house in the medical journal the American Journal of Ophthalmology. The family who lived in this haunted residence, called the H family in the medical literature, began experiencing weird phenomena when they moved into an old house—hearing furniture moving around and strange voices in the night, feeling the presence of invisible specters. They report being held down in bed by ghosts, feeling weak, and more. As it turned out, a faulty furnace was filling their house with carbon monoxide, causing aural and visual hallucinations. The furnace was fixed, and the H family went back to their lives, sans ghosts. 5. SOMEONE ELSE SAID IT WAS REAL. In a 2014 study, Goldsmiths, University of London psychologists had participants watch a video of a “psychic” supposedly bending a metal key with his mind. In one condition, study subjects watched the video with a “participant” who was actually working with the researchers and professed to see the key bending. Those subjects were more likely to report that they saw the key bend than subjects who were paired with someone who asserted that the key didn’t bend or said nothing. “One person’s account can influence another person’s memory,” study co-author Christopher French tells mental_floss. If someone else confidently asserts that they saw the ghost, it might influence a fellow eye-witness to believe they saw it, too. 6. WE WANT TO BELIEVE. “There is a motivational side to belief in ghosts,” French explains. “We all want to believe in life after death. The idea of our mortality is one we are not generally comfortable with.” Confirmation bias holds powerful sway over our perceptions. “We find it much easier to believe evidence for something we want to believe in.” Source: 6 Scientific Explanations for Ghost

No. Or more specifically, not yet. The ability to prove the existence of ghosts is beyond our current scientific ability. Our current toolset is archaic at best. EVPs? Orbs on film? Very little of that “evidence” would convince anyone with an objective mind. But science is a funny thing. Current scientific theory will point towards one conclusion, but then someone(s) will (eventually) come up with indisputable evidence to prove that conclusion wrong. “No balloon and no aeroplane will ever be practically successful” - Lord Kelvin“There is not the slightest indication that nuclear energy will ever be obtainable. It would mean that the atom would have to be shattered at will” - Albert Einstein“If excessive smoking actually plays a role in the production of lung cancer, it seems to be a minor one.” - W.C. Heuper, National Cancer Institute, 1954But how can the best minds of their time be so wrong? It’s because science isn’t static. We can only draw the best conclusions that we can, using the best tools, data, and reasoning that we CURRENTLY have. The conclusion changes when new tools, or data (or theories) are discovered. The following is the best analogy I can think of, of science as it relates to ghosts: In 1809, Nicolas Appert, a French confectioner and brewer, invented “canned food”. He observed that food cooked inside a sealed jar did not spoil. But no one understood how it worked, as it was beyond the current level of what science could explain. But it was impossible to argue that it did work, as the results were easily reproducible and observable. So imagine ghosts are the “canned goods” in the analogy above… except that there is no reliable way to observe ghosts. With the canning example above, even if you can’t explain how it worked, if you put food in a can, sealed it, and heated it, you would have observable proof of the results (that the food doesn’t spoil). But in the ghost analogy where the ghosts are the “food”… you can’t get the food to reliably appear (much less put it in a can, seal it, etc). So all we have are eyewitness testimonies and unconvincing “evidence” from our recording and measuring devices. It’s not enough. At least not yet. But it’s slowly getting better, as we better understand space, time and energy. To all the naysayers that say ghosts don’t exist because science can’t prove their existence? Science has been wrong before. So please try to keep an open mind.

There is no such thing as ghosts. But I had a cat that died and for weeks afterward I would see him from the corner of my eye, typically in spots her would always be sitting such as the top of the speaker or the end of the bed. But when I directed my attention directly to the spot he would not be there. Was it a ghost? Our brain helps fill in the images of our normal everyday surroundings so it won’t have to process the information from our eyes. When you are on familiar turf, the majority of your peripheral vision is made up of “ghost” images because our brain is always seeking the path of least resistance. However, sometimes our brain isn’t yet aware that something has since vanished. Even when we’re consciously aware of the items absence, the impression is still fixed in our sub-conscious memory. Like my cat. For example, someone could steal a painting off a wall and the owner may pass by the wall several time before he realizes the painting is missing. It’s also why you can spot a tourist from a local, locals are barely watching were they’re going but when you see a tourist walking down the same street it’s as if he has head on a swivel.

At the moment, no, but it really depends what you mean by a “ghost.” I am going to assume that we are talking about apparitions of deceased persons, visual sightings. In general such sightings do show some consistency. The figure is seen as a solid form, indistinguishable from that of a living person. However, in some cases it seems to be moving independently of its surroundings, in the sense that it does not appear to see or respond to the witnesses. These cases are sometimes explained as residual energy/stone tape phenomena, where the witness is picking up information that has been recorded in the environment. A more recent interpretation is that of a time slip. In a few cases, however, the ghost does respond to witnesses, often trying to get their attention, sometimes trying to resolve some unfinished business from their life. In a few cases people who have been murdered communicate the names of their killers. In general it would be impossible for science as it now stands to integrate these data into current theory. The more common response is denial. However, a few scientists have continued to study the phenomenon and it is possible that breakthroughs will occur in the future. In cases where the ghost does appear to be a deceased human, the implication is clear that it exists in some other dimension not yet recognised by current science.
